REQ-ADO-001.summary: Each document type shall follow a consistent template (sections, headings, tables) to ensure uniform outputs across projects

REQ-ADO-002.summary: Produce an architecture overview describing the system's purpose, context, key components, and main data/control flows

REQ-ADO-003.summary: Use C4-style context diagrams as the default notation for architecture overviews

REQ-ADO-004.summary: Produce a design specification covering module responsibilities, interfaces, data models, error-handling strategies, and non-functional constraints

REQ-ADO-005.summary: Produce a deployment and operational runbook covering environments, infrastructure topology, CI/CD steps, configuration, scaling strategy, observability, and SLOs

REQ-ADO-006.summary: Produce a PRD/SRS hybrid document covering user goals, functional requirements, quality attributes, acceptance criteria, and dependencies

REQ-INP-001.summary: Supply business goals and target users as input to the agent

REQ-INP-002.summary: Supply success metrics as input to the agent

REQ-INP-003.summary: Supply regulatory or infrastructure limits as input to the agent

REQ-INP-004.summary: Supply prioritized functional requirements as architectural drivers

REQ-INP-005.summary: Supply quality-attribute scenarios as architectural drivers

REQ-INP-006.summary: Supply concerns and constraints in structured form (e.g., separate markdown or tables)

REQ-INP-007.summary: Supply repository snapshot and high-level description as existing system context

REQ-INP-008.summary: Supply any blessed patterns or reference architectures the agent shall reuse

REQ-INP-009.summary: Supply naming conventions as guardrails for the agent

REQ-INP-010.summary: Supply diagram notation (C4 / UML) preferences as guardrails for the agent

REQ-INP-011.summary: Supply document voice and tone preferences as guardrails for the agent

REQ-INP-012.summary: Supply decision rules categorized as Always / Ask First / Never (e.g., never store PII, ask before choosing a DB)

REQ-INP-013.summary: For large systems, the agent shall work against an indexed codebase / document store rather than raw, ad-hoc pastes, so descriptions and diagrams are grounded in reality

REQ-GEN-001.summary: The agent shall outline sections, open questions, and assumptions before writing full prose

REQ-GEN-002.summary: Start with coarse documents (context + containers) before detailed content

REQ-GEN-003.summary: Iterate into components, interfaces, and deployment details progressively

REQ-GEN-004.summary: Update earlier diagrams as the design evolves

REQ-GEN-005.summary: After each phase (drivers, architecture, detailed design, deployment), a human must approve or comment

REQ-GEN-006.summary: Feed diffs and comments back so the agent revises rather than rewriting from scratch

REQ-GEN-007.summary: The agent shall include a Validation / Open Issues section listing assumptions, risks, and items to confirm

REQ-GEN-008.summary: The agent shall perform a consistency check against the original requirements

REQ-GEN-009.summary: Use separate runs/agents for code vs. documentation (e.g., one agent generates the spec, another implements against it) to keep the design stable and auditable

REQ-CST-001.summary: Map requirements to architectural drivers to design decisions

REQ-CST-002.summary: Maintain traceability in small tables the agent keeps up to date

REQ-CST-003.summary: Capture key trade-offs (chose X over Y because...) instead of only describing the final design

REQ-CST-004.summary: Document performance budgets in each specification

REQ-CST-005.summary: Document reliability targets in each specification

REQ-CST-006.summary: Document security boundaries in each specification

REQ-CST-007.summary: Document observability requirements in each specification

REQ-CST-008.summary: Document how the design meets each non-functional requirement

REQ-CST-009.summary: Document model names and versions used in the system

REQ-CST-010.summary: Document prompting strategy used in the system

REQ-CST-011.summary: Document tools used by the agent system

REQ-CST-012.summary: Document safety policies governing the agent system

REQ-CST-013.summary: Document configuration parameters for the agent system

REQ-CST-014.summary: Follow LLM system-engineering guidelines for all agent documentation

REQ-CST-015.summary: For C4, sequence, and deployment diagrams, generate text-based specs (PlantUML, Mermaid) under a Diagrams section

REQ-CST-016.summary: Ensure all diagrams are versionable and reviewable

REQ-DLP-001.summary: Store generated documents in the repository

REQ-DLP-002.summary: Wire an agent into CI to flag drift between code and documentation (e.g., changed endpoints, config keys, queues)

REQ-DLP-003.summary: Use orchestration (e.g., LangGraph or equivalent) so one agent updates architecture documents when another introduces significant structural changes

REQ-DLP-004.summary: The system shall retrieve relevant sections of past documents as context when generating new ones

REQ-DLP-005.summary: Maintain consistent terminology and patterns across documents

REQ-DLP-006.summary: Define who signs off on architecture and deployment documents

REQ-DLP-007.summary: Require sign-off before certain CI stages (e.g., infrastructure changes) can proceed
